reviewText:
I purchased this game as part of the Saints Row Ultimate Franchise Pack, which was on sale at the time for about $18.  I can honestly say this game has left me completely satisfied with my purchase, and despite having bought the bundle at the beginning of the summer, and played every day, it was at least a month before I even opened Saints Row 3 for the first time, because I was having so much fun playing Saints Row 2, and there is simply that much to do.  With 233.8 hours on record as of my review, I still am only at about 95-97% completion on my first and only playthrough, because it was simply too much fun screwing around.  Even after finishing the story missions, of which there are more than enough to make the game worth buying all by itself, there was still so much to do.

The controls took a bit of getting used to, but only at first.  After a short while, any oddities control-wise felt completely natural, which is far from always the case when talking about ported titles.  The only thing I could recommend a controller for would be the driving/piloting.  While driving ground vehicles, the WASD keys don't quite give you the best experience, but they work perfectly fine for it.  The main complaint I had about the game in general were the flight controls, which were awkward at first, but even after getting used to the layout, which wasn't that strange, it still lacked the ability to make small adjustments without losing control, unless you practice a lot. (I practiced a lot though, and mostly was able to work around it.) I got so accustomed to the keybindings in this game that I actually changed most of my SR3 keybindings to match (where they were different at least) because I found I honestly missed many of the default keybindings where they had been changed.  Still, using a console controller for the air vehicles is probably your best option, if nothing else.

The graphics are far from amazing by current standards, but considering the time the game was made, they're perfectly solid, and the water still looks more real than watch dogs (you actually have a wake in a boat! HOW ADVANCED!! Sorry had to. considering I got this game in a huge bundle for only 18 dollars, I am not only satisfied, I would gladly have paid $18 dollars for this game alone, if I evaluated the value of the game solely on the amount of fun I had playing it.  All in all, I fully recommend this game and hope others enjoy it as much as I have.

reviewText:
The best Saints Row game made to this day.. The others are bigger and crazier but this one is the real deal.

It has the most alive city. There are lots of different individuals. People, constructions, cars and general theme changes from district the district. So you never get the feeling of hanging around same place over and over again.

Story is what it should be in an open world game. Three enemy gangs and you want to end them all. Simple. But the way they present it with missions is really impressive. There are lots of touching moments as well as action packed ones. In some mission I felt so angry that I find myself finishing all of the gangs mission in one play.

In my opinion GTA was always very linear. This one has three set of missions that you can do in whatever order you want. And if you are bored from doing it you have tons of funny activities.

Customization options are huge. For cars, gang and yourself. There are some crazy and useless ones but you could nearly create and ideal character for your taste.

So any cons? Yeah of course. Driving is kinda hard. Cars don't respond right most of the time and you feel driving a paper car or something. Graphics are out of date of course (which is not a problem for me because I have and old computer). Finishing activities can be so much hard sometimes, 6 level a bit hard, 3 is ideal I think. There are some bugs in some missions and graphics but they are not a big deal. And there are some problems with the default controls but I'm sure you can make it work. You get used to after a while.

In conclusion this game still has it. It has all the right touches. Yes it is an old game but still one of the best open world game I have played. I give it at least an 8 out 10. It is not expensive. So you should try it...

PS: You know what makes this game better, steam achievements.. And trading cards... Ohh I wish...
PS-2: I didn't play any other version of the game so I couldn't compare them. But this one worked just nice for my PC.

reviewText:
I‚Äôm glad I decided to play this game! The only reason I started playing it was because I finished Saints Row 4 and loved it, which made me want more. As it turns out Saints Row 2 feels like it hardly belongs in the same franchise as the fourth game. Volition have truly reinvented the franchise as they‚Äôve gone from title to title, only keeping the characters and setting as they go. This explains why the people who loved the second game and wanted more of that tend to complain loudly about the third and fourth games. They‚Äôre just not the same. Personally I think reinventing and iterating are both equally valid approaches for a series to take. I like the variety, and you certainly can‚Äôt accuse them of retreading the same ground like I‚Äôve seen some do with Rockstar and the GTA series.

Saints Row 2 came out in 2008, and it feels like a game of its time. It might not seem like 2008 is that far back, but when you play games of that time they all feel old now, as does Saints Row 2. At that time I remember games journalists were talking about emergent gameplay instead of story, and it shows in Saints Row 2‚Äôs design. Compared to any major game released in 2013 this feels like complete chaos. Instead of the world acting like a virtual movie set with carefully staged combat, the game instead relies on world simulation systems and AI to act on its own. This approach makes it nearly impossible for a developer to tell a story during missions, because the minute to minute gameplay is completely unpredictable. Instead the designer only choreographs the action with commands like: Go there, kill that, chase that car, etc.

Even during missions the world simulation present in the free exploration mode is in full effect. So when you take over areas of the map you‚Äôll have friendly thugs spawn there. If a mission happens to take place there, or a car chase goes through neighborhoods controlled by your gang, groups of friendly thugs will spawn and rain bullets on your pursuers. If during a mission an enemy shoots a civilian standing near you, police will arrive on the scene and start fighting the enemy gangsters with you. The last time I saw this kind of three way combat break out spontaneously was in the Stalker games. I wish we had more games like this, especially on the next-gen consoles where the extra memory and power could allow much more elaborate world simulation. That would in some way fulfill ‚Äúthe point‚Äù of next-gen hardware. Making something you couldn‚Äôt do on 360/ps3, just like this game is something that couldn‚Äôt exist on PS2.

Anyway, I had a great time blowing through this game. It‚Äôs messy, ugly, glitch, but it all comes together to create something special. One thing I was pleasantly surprised by was the quality of the cutscenes. In Saints Row 4 they were generally very high quality, but in a couple scenes I found the sound to be a bit crap. In Saints Row 2 the sound during cutscenes is phenomenal. It‚Äôs raw, violent and has about as much impact as you could hope to have. It fits perfectly with the story itself which in the ‚ÄúBrotherhood‚Äù missions turns into an ugly conflict where neither side appear noble or heroic in any way. It‚Äôs dark, gruesome and I was even shocked at one scene where the game made it abundantly clear that the player isn‚Äôt a hero anyone should aspire to be. So I finally get where the hype about Saints Row 2 has come from. If you know you‚Äôre a fan of slightly janky games with outstanding qualities you‚Äôll probably like this. Those wanting a slick, modern, controlled experience should avoid it like the plague.

reviewText:
‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• port
I'll start off by saying that the pc port is absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Even on the best hardware around this game will not stay at a stable 60 fps on high settings. But I still prefer the pc version over the console version. On the xbox 360 and ps3 the game often goes below 30 fps and crashes from time to time. At least the pc version never crashed when I played it and it never went below 30 fps on my pc. Also the online doesn't work anymore because gamespy closed down, so if you want to play with a friend you need to use hamachi or evolve and run a lan game.

With that out of the way, let the real review begin.
It's one of the most enjoyable games I ever played. It may even be one of my favorite games of all times for many reasons. But the #1 reason has to be the humor and the near perfect balance of semi-serious crime drama and wacky comedy. I found myself laughing almost all the way trough the story. If I like humor so much then why don't I think that SR3 and 4 are better? Well the fun moments are so balanced out that it works that much better. In SR4 it bombards you with funny things but you get too used to it. In SR2 the funny moments are balanced out so that you don't get used to things being whacky and you'll apreciate the fun/whacky moments more for it.

There also is the crazy amount of custumization in the game. You can decide at what angle you tilt your hat. I don't think I need to say more than that.

The gameplay is pretty standard. It plays like a modern version of the ps2 gta games. But the minigames are amazing. You can join a wrestling club, spray poop on houses to devalue the land,  pretend to get hurt to claim insurance, steal hookers from their pimps, ride a burning quad though the city and more. I'm not kidding. These are actual minigames. There are also standard ones like racing, being a hitman, stealing certain cars, etc. I do hate the fact that you need to complete mini games to unlock story missions but I probably wouldn't have played them otherwise.

The music is also pretty good. I really like the 80's radio station. There are cd shops in the city where you can buy music to make a mic tape with to listen to in your car on the way to your next burning quad time trial. (I especially love Out of Touch and Down Under).

The entire story is playable in co-op and you will see your own charcter in the cutscenes (not the host's character). What I mean by that is that you will get more enjoyement out of the game itself with a friend while you still expierience the entire story like you were playing alone.

My final point is: It's only 10 euros or your regional equivalent when it's not on sale. In the sale it's usually 2,50 euros.
This game is easily worth 20 euros.

Verdict
I love SR2 and I see no reason to not tell you to buy this if you haven't already. And if you are still on the fence wait until it's on sale and get it then.  Having said that I will recommend checking if your pc can run this. The recommended system requirements do not garuantee that the game will work at a stable 30 fps!

reviewText:
GTA with a fun storyline (though it can get more than a tad gruesome in parts) and a lot of crazy fun stuff to do as side missions. The game can be fully co-oped if you wish but its plenty fun solo as well.

The driving is arcadey but works just fine with the keyboard+mouse combo in my experience. The character generator is top notch and the clothing selection and permutations allowed really makes it possible to make your character look pretty much as you want him to which adds a lot to the game if this matters to you.

The only real issues with the game are technical ones. The FPS limiting doesn't let you maximize the use of your card and you are basically stuck at 30 FPS and lower for most of the game at your 'ideal' settings. Also there might be an issue with the game running too slow or too fast but it didn't arise for me. The fix is easy to google though.

If you got a decent machine or better don't let these issues discourage you if you enjoy open word mayhem.

reviewText:
This game has to be one of my favorites of all time.
Character creation is amazing, so many customization options. I made Nigel Thornberry.
The story is actually really good and immersive and invokes genuine feelings, you really hate the antagonists.
The game is just the right amount of crazy, the third and fourth games went off the deep end and while they were still entertaining, the story wasn't really as serious as it was in this game.
The difficulty was alright, it wasn't irrationally hard but it didn't seem overly easy.
It was genuinely fun to play and the characters were well developed.
I highly recommend the game, it's definitely worth the money and time. My only negative thing is the multiplayer, it's very difficult to connect with friends, but possible. I do truly love this game despite that, and it's definitely worth the dollars.

reviewText: Well where should I start.. This game is (atleast by my opinion) the best installment in the franchise. I had alot of fun with it I must say.  STORY: Do you need to know the story of the first game? Well no but it's better if you do because there are some characters from the first Saints Row aswell as some references to it. I think the story is pretty decent (Even though there are about 8-9 missions and about 4-5 Stronghold mission for one gang). There are some touching moments (Most of them referring to the first game). GAMEPLAY: So I need to say that the combat with guns is pretty balanced. You can use just one pistol or two pistols in both hands but with having only one you have better aim but you can deal less damage at the time and if you use two of them you get less accurate but at close range you'll deal more damage (You see where I'm going?). This gives you the freedom in choosing what do you want to have. Then you have here the Respect Bar which serves for doing missions. When you level up your Respect Bar you can play missions. That means for example if you have no level in your Respect bar (Which decreases after doing a mission BTW) you can't play a mission. You need to do some side-activities to gain Respect and with it you can play missions afterwards. Which makes the game pretty long but yet still fun to play. Then you've got alot of shops for buying clothes,food (food in this game serves as a quick regeneration of your health),weapons,music for your very own radio and more. GRAPHICS: Well.. I won't talk about graphics being ugly because the game is pretty old but in my opinionthey're pretty good but the thing here is how the game is optimized. To be honest it has pretty bad console port. Sometimes it get's unplayable when you get into a larger fight. But you can reduce that to minimum or get rid of it completely by some methods and programs. But my final verdict about this game is 9.5/10 because if it didn't had those problems with optimization I would gladly give it 10/10.

reviewText:
I went into this game with low expectations, since what I played of the first Saints Row was more-or-less a GTA clone. But I was really surprised at how awesome this game is. In the first hour of the game I witnessed a samurai ninja gang member run after and attack a female streaker who was running around taunting people, followed by a guy walking around in a hotdog costume. On top of this, I discover a song by my favorite band on one of the in game radio stations. At this point, this was already an awesome game and I enjoyed most of my time playing it.

In this game you play as the leader of the Saints, the same character from the first game, and you have to take over the city of Stilwater once again from three new gangs. Each gang had unique, well written generals and leaders, and the boss fights with them were quite interesting, though in some cases frustrating because of iffy controls. There was lots of humor in the game, some of it unintentional, but this really helped the game stand apart from the standard GTA formula.

I had few issues with the game apart from the two or three annoying bosses. Most of the cars are really bad to drive in, either slow, or bad handling. I stuck to a police car for most of the game. Fast, and turns well. I also had problems with checkpoints forcing me to redo entire missions after something like an apache helicopter appears out of nowhere and I can't avoid it and die. This gets annoying but overall, it didn't hurt the overall gameplay.

The best thing about this game is that it's fun. There's a lot of wacky stuff in here, like driving around in a septic truck and spraying houses and stuff to lower property values and whatnot. This game is unique and memorable, and I think I enjoyed the game more than GTA. And this is only the beginning. From what I've heard, the games just get wackier and more epic from this point, but this was an excellent starting point for me, since I can't really play the first Saints Row.

TL;DR
This game is fun, unique, the story is strong, and the characters are memorable. Play this game!

8/10
Awesome!

reviewText:
Great game: terrible PC port.

I was waiting to get this game on steam a long time ago, and then a Volition sale happened coincidentally. So I bought it, started it up, and was excited to play quite possibly the best SR game on PC. After having to click through the main menu using only my arrow keys (no mouse support on the title screen), I was finally able to start the game. The graphics seemed a bit bad when compared to the console versions, but I wasn't going to let graphics stop me from playing. So I created my custom character, and after watching the following cutscene, all of my hope of this being a good PC port officially sank.

As soon as I was allowed to move around (after the cutscene you have to break out of jail), I noticed that everything was moving faster than it should have been: character movements, their animations, you name it (though the sound effects were still normal). This makes the game nearly impossible to play-since it's so hard to aim weapons and driving is incredibly awkward (on a side note, they didn't even bother to change the weapon change pop-up from the Xbox version, click). Why exactly is the game like this? Well that's because when Volition ported SR2 from Xbox to PC, they didn't bother optimizing the CPU speed for it (SR2's is about 3.2 Ghz) so that it could work well with the CPU speed for most computers (source, see IdolNinja's 4th post). To put it in English, while it'll run perfectly fine on the Xbox, it'll run like crap on most PCs (this speed-up" glitch happens on both Windows 7 and 8). If you think I'm the only one with this problem
date: check the community hub for this game and you'll see that tons of people have the same problem.\n\nNow I've heard that there is a way this can be fixed by using an external mod known as Gentlemen of the Row
recommended: but that's beside the point. The fact that I'm forced to restort to an external mod to fix a game that should have already been fixed is just ridiculous. If you want to play Saints Row 2
hoursPlayed: pick up an Xbox or PS3 version. Do not waste your time on this lackluster PC port."

reviewText:
At 1st I wanted to give a positive vote, but after several technical issues, I unfortunately have to give a negative one.

Pros:
- lots of stuff to do
- driving around is fun
- over-the-top world, thus the violence isn't realistic either and become fun (eg: you hit an old lady with your car ? If you stop, she'll pull you out of your seat and beat the crap out of you! :-P )
- nice gang built-up feeling, from being no one to being a street king

Cons:
- voice audio is of poor quality, because compressed too much, which is a bit of a mood killer
- it randomly crashes, so you'll need a Mod to fix some of them (check here => http://steamcommunity.com/app/9480/discussions/0/846958724811426425/ ; I didn't try it by myself though)
- no quick save, so when it crashes, I had to restart the mission from the very start
- framerate is often bad outside, and very bad inside (with I7 4.3ghz + NVidia GTX 760)
- there's no difficulty per se ; ie: my skills weren't tested much ; it was more my patience & my nerves that were tested against badly designed controls
- infinite waves of enemies in some missions ; when I just killed 50 gang members, I'd like to feel I made some void in their ranks, not that they can keep spawning at an insane rate no matter what

If you don't mind the cons (or can fix them with some Mods), then go for it, you might enjoy the game ! :-)

reviewText: Great game. Lots of violence, which treads the line between funny and horrifying. Your character is an unapologetic ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, which would suck in any other game, but here it's made fun. There are tons of sidemissions which you have to complete to get Respect for story missions and each Activity's premise is hilariously idiotic. The witing is equally great in all the cutscenes and it's just a delight to watch them. The licensed OST is rather good, with the highlight for me being flying around in a helicopter and exploding a rival gang's vehicles to the sound of The Subway's Rocknroll Queen. While we are on the matter of vehicles, they look great and some are VERY fast, but they handle like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. When you get to the third or fourth mission of the Ronin, my advice is to spawn a helicopter with a cheat before you start, because there's always ONE biker that gets away. The regenerating health system is rather ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in this case, which is why I sometimes used the full health cheat. Another gripe I have is the driver AI, even members of your own gang will slam their car in yours when you're speeding somewhere.\n\nBut, overall it's a great game with a somewhat ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• port (done by CD Projekt no less) and I reccommend it to anyone who wants a great, self-aware gangster story. God knows Saints Row 2 is the last sane games in the series and I look forward to palying 3 and 4.

reviewText:
It's a blast... when it works.

I've played and beaten it before on 360 and it was extremely fun; pretty much selling me on the Saints Row 2-4 bundle as soon as I noticed that it was available on Steam.  Unfortunately, this port constantly crashes for me, even after following tweaking guides and using the vastly recommended 'Gentlemen of the Row' patch.  The patch adds great features, like supposed stability tweaks that didn't work for me, in-game PS3/360 button prompts, and additional clothing/walking/customization options that were already in the game but isn't available for the player to access otherwise.  Sadly, what this patch does for this port is what should have done by the developers in the first place.  I just find it extremely unfortunate that such a great game suffers from such a terrible port.

Overall recommendation: If you feel like tweaking the game and are ready to grab a refund if it doesn't work for you; go for it.  Pass and avoid otherwise.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games. :D

PROS:
+ Quite good storyline.

CONS:

- You can't replay cutscenes from activities.

I rate it 8 out of 10. If there weren't all those bugs, crashes and performance issues, I'd give it 9,5 out of 10. :)

reviewText:
This game is a crazy good time! Or at least, it would be a crazy good time if it werent for the game's poor coding on PC. Don't get me wrong, this game is awsome. But for whatever reason the PC version absolutely chugs and sputters.

Even on my Intel Core I7-3770K CPU with 16GB of RAM, an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 670, and a Windows 7 Ultimate 64-bit operating system, the game ran at about twenty and seven FPS and had a whole host of other performance issues/bugs. In other words, it was nauseating and almost unplayable. Even the games controls can feel wonky and/or hyper sensitive at times. The core gameplay is the same mind you, but the general performance basically kills the entire experience.

So until this game is patched to work with modern operating systems, computers components, and has a general preformance overhual I just can't recommend this game.

Edit: I would like to also add that this version of Saints Row 2 is a compatability issues nightmare and was an overall headache to just get running in the first place.

reviewText: Saints Row 2 is an enjoyable game. Having played all of the SR games on PC, if I had to pick a favorite it would be The Third. This game is a little weaker mechanically, and can take a lot of effort to even get running. Even more to get it running without the cutscenes bugging out. The guns feel wimpy at times, especially the pistols. The customisation is the most in-depth of any SR game, and if you just ignore it you aren't enjoying all this game has to offer. The story is absolutely superb, and very dark. Sadly, the low quality audio files in this port can ruin some moments. Co-Op is a blast provided you get it to work. The AI both realistically and frustratingly realize they are rolling around in two-ton bullets, and kill you very quickly on higher heat levels.\n\nTL:DR; The game has problems, most of which stem from being a bad port and are being worked on by both the modding community and the developers in their spare time. The story is entertaining but there are some balance issues. Customisation is utterly unrivaled by any crime sandbox game on the market today, except for potentially Saints Row IV.

reviewText:
Saints Row 2 was once upon a time one of my favorite console games. Infact I'd say it was the main reason I bought an xbox 360 and all the experiences I had I'll cherish for the rest of my life.

However, I will be the first to admit this game has not aged well by any stretch of the imagination. The animation work is simply amazingly bad, the voice acting is terrible and the modelling work is simplistic. However, the game world still features a significant amount of depth. With numerous collectables and secret areas that litter the landscape of Stilwater. The player character customization was only reduced in SR3 to put it into perspective.

The biggest problem with this game today is the PC port, which is today known as the worst PC port in the history of gaming. You would normally require an extensive knowlege with hex editors inorder to run the game natively. But thankfully the modding community has released Gentlemen of the Row" which fixes pretty much all the problems and even adds functionality to the game that didn't previously exist in the 360/PS3 release. If your at all curious about SR2 it's pretty much mandatory to run this mod."

reviewText:
Saints Row 2 is, in my opinion, one of the best video games ever. Everything about this game is awesome. This game has some of the best cutscenes I've ever seen in a video game. The brutality of the deaths of major characters in cutscenes is amazing, my reaction to them are mostly 'Holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that was awesome.' I personally love the story and can't wait to play mission after mission. The music in this game is pretty solid, and I'm very picky about music. The diversions are fun as hell, whether you're spraying feces on people or blowing up everything you can find. This game is pretty fun and sometimes pretty weird, but that's what makes it so great.

The pc port is not great, but it is not nearly as bad as other reviews make it seem. There were several issues that lowered the quality of my experience in the game, but after a while I got used to them. My game has only crashed once and I currently have 18.7 hours in game. Don't let the bad pc port hold you back from purchasing this masterpiece. If you are having trouble with it then you can read other reviews where they talk about how they fixed their game, like downloading Gentlemen of the Row.

Overall, Saints Row 2 is a great game, and a fun game. I absolutely recommend this game to everybody. I give this game a 10/10.

reviewText:
Saints Row 2 (Played on the Highest Difficulty)

Positives:

+ Cool unlockable rewards which benefit gameplay, including rare weapons, unlimited ammo and new cars.
+ Variety of powerful weapons for melee and gun combat.
+ Assortment of activites to complete, including drug trafficking, celebrity bodyguard protection, fight club and much more.
+ Good music soundtrack for radio stations.
+ Decent storyline.
+ 70 to 80 hours of gameplay for completionists.

Negatives:

- Terrible PC Port, some people literally may not be able to play the game even if you have a beast gaming computer.
- Poor graphics for a game released in early 2009.
- Can be frustrating on occasions (at least on the highest difficulty) but still achievable.
- Friendly AI is incredibly stupid and essentially sabotages your chance at success. For example, during drug trafficking activities where you need to protect the drug dealer, the AI drives vehicles to a meeting point but usually just crashes into cars along the way, damaging the vehicle.

Overall Score: 6.5/10

A fun game but not without serious flaws.

reviewText:
Saints Row 2 is the first of the Saints Row franchise to be released on PC, with the 1st game being an Xbox exclusive. Following on from 5 years after the events of the original game, you set about trying to reinstate the Third Street Saints gang as the occupiers of the city of Stillwater. With the main story progression slowly wiping out the rival gangs, there are lots of smaller side missions that allow you to earn respect from your gang and the citizens of Stillwater. The hyperrealistic gameplay and humerous jokes make the game enjoyable to play, allowing to relax and zone out after a long day at the office.

I've seen many reviews complaining about this being a bad port, however I have had no issues that are really worth mentioning.

Pros:
+ Open world environment allowing exploration and free play
+ Customizable character, goons, vehicles, and cribs
+ Enjoyable main story, with plenty of fun and comical side misssions
+ Hyperrealistic gameplay adds to the humour and atmosphere of the game
+ Fantasic set of characters with nice dialogue and voice acting
+ Enjoyable cutscenes to watch

Cons:
- Helicopters are so hard to control!
- No achievements
- Potential optimization problems (I didn't experience any though)

My Score: 7/10

reviewText:
This, in my opinion, is the BEST Saints Row game out of the few I've played-SR IV, SRTT, SR2-.
This game has the best story out of the Saints Row games I've played, and has the best map out of any SR games I've played. Note: this review will have spoilers.
Pros:
The map may not be the largest map of any open world sandbox game I've played, but it's one of the best, just under GTA V's in explorability-in my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• little opinion-. I've played over 170 hours of it, and I'm still finding new locations and secrets.
Unlike SRTT, the game encourages exploration to find secret areas and secret CD's that you can collect for extra tracks on your custom playlists for the radio, and to unlock new outfits for every 10 you find.
SRTT's map, in my opinion, is too bland and industrial, just a boring city. Steelport is boring, honestley-and the map was reused in SR IV which sucks major ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-. Stilwater-WITH ONE 'L', ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•- is actually  reused, but because of-SPOILERS- Ultor fixing up the city, it looks different than what I've seen of SR1's version of Stilwater.
It's pedestrians are varied, and they have different spawns for different areas. In SRTT, the peds don't stand out and are boring.
The story is great, showing how-SPOILERS- the boss is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing socipathic killer, and will ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up anybody in his/her way. He ruins the lives of his enemies, cripples them, buries them alive, ruins family relationships, kills their loved ones. One scene legitemetley makes me ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing terrified, and is one of my greatest fears,-SPOILERS-, being buried alive.
There's plenty of customization option to make your little man/woman pretty. Under shirts, over shirts, coats, eyewear, different singular piercings, TEETH, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING, EYES-if you get GoTR-, pants, underwear, SOCKS-THAT HIGHLY DETAILED-, and shoes. You can change the colors of all of them, make them look different, different styles to wear them and how they look. It's the best feature in the game
The music is great, and I usually play with it off, but I'd reccomend keeping it on and listening to the radio.
The food/drug wheel makes a return from SR1, but has much more limited options than in the last game, and it's a visual effect. Drugs used to give you different abilities while making your damage intake lower, but your screen more covered in smoke. Beer would make you vomit-if you consumed too much-, and would make your vision blurry, but your melee damage would be heavily increased. Food gave you health. Now it's just visual for the drugs and beer, no actual upgrades given. Food still heals though.
The missions are fun, for the most part.

But with the amazingly kick-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, must come the bad.

Cons:
It's PC port is a DISASTER, and I reccomend a mod to fix all the bugs, add new weapons, and 2 of the few DLC missions ported over-GoTR-.
It's graphics seem a bit outdated, but I don't really mind it.
Even for 2008, the draw distance is horrible.
Some missions have a time limit, and those seem to be the most tedious ones.
Even with the Gentlemen of The Row mod, if you get over 30 FPS items float away from charecters in cutscenes, or are just a bit off. I can't really describe it.
With the 2 DLC missions ported over-Corporate Warfare and the other one I can't remember- with GoTR, they're unfinished, which I can't blame them for, and even on the consoles it's a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ending to a big part of what happened in SR1 at the end of the game. You ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing get blown up on a yacht, Dex, Troy, and Julius ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed you over. With the Corporate Warfare DLC Dex re-appeared and you got to do some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Now, it ended in a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing horrid way, with Dex just getting on his plane from the airport, and flying away.-SPOILERS- But there is actually clarifacation on what happened to Dex, his plane crashed in Steelport, you can see it in SRTT and SR IV, and he died.
The ending seems a bit to happy from what I expect of SR, in SR1 you got blown the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up, in SRTT theres an option to-spoilers- let Shaundi die and you go to kill Killbane, which is the ending I prefer. In SR2 you basicially take over the city and boom. Hardly anyone ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing died. Yeah, Aisha died, Carlos died, Gat got stabbed and was in the hospital for a while, Shaundi got kidnapped by Veteran Child, who you kill, but, it seemed a bit to happy for what I expected.-I played SR IV first, then SR TT, and then SR2.-

Overall, with the GoTR mod, I give this game a 8/10, a great game. Now, I installed the mod off the bat, so I can't give a rating for the unmodded game. But, yeah, this game is the best SR game in my opinion, and if you haven't bought/played it yet, it's only 10 bucks, and it's worth much more than that.

reviewText: SR2 is best played first if you want to get into the series on PC. You'll need the Gentlemen of the Row mod too because it fixes the bad port's problems but even then I still have had the game randomly crash at times. Overall the game is good, but its not nearly as fun as 3 and 4. Sure Stillwater is more interesting to explore and there's more customization options but the combat is rather bland. You only get crazy weapons until towards the end of the game so you're stuck with your standard sandbox arsenal and none of them really feel satisfying. Also its kind of feels like the series didn't find its identity yet and SR2 tries to balance being serious and silly and it doesn't really work. Personally I think people overhype this game, but its still worth playing.

reviewText: The game is fun and addicting and can sometimes be a good sandbox game if not for it's annoying hinderances. The game lacks optimization, if you use anything above a 3.0ghz CPU then you will find everything to be 2x faster and this can only be solved by either downloading a software or lowering your CPU clock down to 3.0 if you have it overclocked. The driving in this game is exceptionally raging, at times I have had to restart missions  because the vehicles would just handle very badly and sometimes stearing myself into objects/buildings and blowing the car up, especially at high speeds. The framerates are horrible even though I have a multi-core CPU my framerates stutter a lot, this is most noticable when driving and so far I haven't found a solution to this. I feel as if the developers didn't take enough time to optimize it because most of the games controls feel very awkward. This game ends up being a enjoyable but buggy/badly optimized mess and should be avoided.\n\nEDIT: I forgot to add but the game itself is pretty damn good, the port is just horrible so I recommend you play the console version if possible.

reviewText: This is sandbox how it should be done. Numerous weapons lying around, squishy mortals to use them on, and side missions with the most creative ideas in them. While SR2 is quite similar to a GTA game, there are some core differences. The most obvious one is that, while GTA likes to downplay the inherent anarchy that flourishes within the game, Saint's Row embraces it, and lets you go nuts. For example, the notoriety mechanic. If, at any point, you find yourself surrounded by members of a rival gang, you can choose to begin firing randomly at civilians, by which point cops will come running and take the thugs off your hands. Another example is the cars. Saint's Row 2 completely ignores physics for these bits, and just lets you go wild, smashing through groups of pedestrians with not even a scratch on you.\nMaybe there's some irony in an insane game that knows that it's insane, but I can't really care. I stopped caring while running down the streets in full mime getup clubbing old ladies in the face with a sledgehammer.

reviewText:
This is a bad third-party port. Mouse and keyboard controls basically function (with correct prompts), and it has graphics options, but the performance is all over the place and throws the physics with it. Raw machine power doesn't seem to enter into it: even the end credits scroll can't run smoothly. Some activities (like using the tow truck) will be pure hell.

However, it's also a great game. The writing is strong again, and it's actually got a lot more to it than SR3 or 4. A lot. The city is more varied, more alive (for example, skateboarding pedestrians), and there are a whole heap of entertaining activities. You get to see why Gat is cool, rather than just being told he is. Shaundi is actually likable. Vehicles actually handle distinctly, at least when the physics engine isn't choking to death. There're nice touches like a noticeboard to let you replay past missions and even a TV to rewatch cutscenes in your new duds. If, like me, you started on SR3 and wondered why some people were bemoaning its reduced scope, this game is the explanation. SR3 feels a little more distilled, but this is the bigger, badder game. Between this and 4, well, I lost interest halfway through 4 to focus on this.

If only Volition's paymasters would assign them to actually fix or remake it properly. Call it an HD" re-release if you must; it'd certainly beat another Enter the Dominatrix.

As it is

reviewText:
July 2015: I've gotten a new rig so it's time to update my original review!

So, Saints Row 2 comes with a whole new set of issues with the upgrade to a new (to ME, anyway!) operating system, in this case, Windows 7!  There's a ton of help out there, though, originating from THE go-to source for such info (AKA Idolninja and his Saints Row Mods site) for getting the game to run normally under Win7, so honestly, this wasn't even *slightly* a problem.  Just a few tweaks according to instructions and the game was running perfectly.

That said, there absolutely isn't a reason I can think of to give Saints Row 2 a pass, other than maybe if you still have the (very depressing) combination of severely outdated PC hardware plus ancient operating system.  A modern OS, a modern CPU and moderately speedy RAM all go REALLY far in mitigating any poor performance due to the badly-done port of this game.

Also, having finished Saints Row 4 recently (finally!), I can hands-down say that Saints Row 2 is STILL the best Saints Row of the series.  Sure, the graphics aren't pretty, but did you know there are SweetFX mods out there that beautifully fix this quibble?  There totally ARE, so get this game already if you haven't yet, okay?  Okay!

-------
Original review below:

The PC port notoriously buggy, but if you're lucky, you might get away with not having any showstopping bugs, like me!  It worked fine out of the box, and I'm on some old hardware with an ancient OS (XP).  There's a veritable TON of info out there to fix or minimize the game's bugs (look up the guy named IdolNinja, he's a Saints Row magician), so even if you do have issues, with a bit of tweaking, the game may well run fine for you too.

If you started with Saints Row the Third and want to know some of the Saints' backstory, this is a must-have game.  GET IT GET IT GET IT!  Especially when it's on one of those mega sales where you can get it for $3.74 or so!

reviewText:
This is Saints Row 2, and this is the only time I've ever driven backwards down the sidewalk tossing grenades out the window listening to Culture Club. For the first time in my life, actually experiencing true contentedness (until the game crashed).

First things first: This is a bad port. It's going to crash sometimes, default controls feel a bit like they were slapped together by someone who's never actually used a keyboard, apparently some players are experiencing their games playing at faster speeds than what the game should, the game will stutter here and there, but does this render the game completely unplayable, and does Volition deserve packages of poo delivered to them in the mail?

It could, and possibly.

In the forty-ish hours I've played this game, it's crashed five times. I haven't narrowed down why it does this; it just happens at random. Driving down the sidewalk, outdoors on foot, during missions, not during missions, and one time in the mallwhen I found a little UFO and promptly crashed 10 feet away.

And praise Jesus, for the controls are changeable. Whoever said the F key should be weapon zoom, I hate you, and I bet you're the same turdhound who did it in Red Faction: Guerilla. Seriously. F? You get an F. And the stuttering, for me, with my Frankenstein-like PC, was not a constant. Sometimes it would seem like the car I was driving would stop for a trillionth of a second. It's noticeable, but not game breaking. Just annoying. As for that speed-up issue, I have no idea what that's about. Hasn't happened to me.

Now, to actually review the game. Saints Row 2 has been the most fun I've had playing a game in a really, really long time. In fact it's the first game over twenty hours long that I've actually completed the main story beginning to end. I bought it during the Saints Row free weekend at around 9pm. I ended up playing clear into morning, went to class, then came home and almost started it back up again. But, you know, sleep and all that.

Graphically, Saints Row 2 is both amazing and boring at the same time. Some parts of Stilwater are fantastically detailed while others are pretty bland (but that's true of real life cities, so I guess that point's a bit moot), cars will look different depending on their paint jobs, blood goes flying when you go on murder sprees, trees look like trees, etc.

There will be hilarious glitches, too. Phones will be stuck to fingertips, one NPC's helmet will be off by half a head (hilarious scene, by the way, made even more hilarious because of the glitch), traffic will flip out (literally), and lots of other funny, not game-breaking stuff. I once had a pedestrian get caught in my windshield. His legs were flopping around at the top of the car as I was avoiding the police. Hilarious.

Your character, The Boss, on the other hand, is going to look a bit strange. What I mean is you're going to be able to tell you made him, and not the same guy who modeled the other main characters. My first character, before really taking my time at the plastic surgeon, looked like this. Absolutely horrifying. Eventually, she became a man, then I finally settled on this, so, it is possible to make a character that doesn't look like she can chew through your ribcage and eat your soul, just take your time and eventually you‚Äôll get something you like.

Gameplay-wise, Saints Row 2 has taken what‚Äôs worked in other games and stuck right to it. The game plays very well (once you get used to that stutter I mentioned earlier). Control-wise, you'll need to play in the options menu for a bit to get the camera movement speed how you like it, and you'll have to figure out how to rebind your keys, but once you get all set up how you like it, you won't have any problems.

Vehicle movement may be too sensitive for some people. They didn't take into account W, A, S, and D isn't exactly the same as a control stick, so vehicle control may feel over-sensitive. Helicopters will make you not want to use helicopters. They whip around while turning and when you're trying to stop, they wobble around and then suddenly flip over, crash into a building, get stuck on something and explode.

As you're running around town you can carry one of each type of weapon: Pistol, shotgun, rifle, submachine gun, grenades, and a special weapon, and whatever type the rocket launcher falls into. You also have food in your inventory, and I've been carrying around the same burgers since I started up the game because I never found out how to eat the damn things. You can dual-wield pistols and submachine guns, and also use those two weapons while driving to fire out the window at whoever might be minding their own business while you drive by.

The game map is spattered with things to do. You have the main story missions, then you have what are called Activities. These can be anything from stealing ho's from pimps to driving around on an ATV in a fire suit, setting people on fire. Each activity has six levels, and there are two different locations per activity. Each activity gives some kind of reward, like improved accuracy, damage resistance, faster healing. All very useful, and I wish I knew that before I jumped into the main story missions, because that infinite sprint is really handy. The activities also give you Respect, a stat that determines whether or not you can even do the story missions.


Completing missions and activities reward you money, costumes, cars, bonuses, etc. Eventually you'll find yourself with tons and tons of cash, which you can use to buy stuff to customize your character, trips to the gun store, car dealer, plastic surgeon, and other places. You can buy real estate, and from that you'll have cash deposited in your stash's safe that you can pick up each game day.

There is so much to do in this game that if you get bored, either you've already done everything, or you just don't like the game. This is also one of those games where you can take a break from the game without shutting it down and playing something else. Tired of missions? Go see how long you can survive with your notoriety at five stars. Do some activities like finding the car races around the city or hop in a septic truck and give hundreds of people E. coli. Suffering through those helicopter missions might bring your interest back to other missions!

The actual story of Saints Row 2 is alright. I don't want to ruin anything, but there are some memorable things involving monster trucks and boats. I've already mentioned the story is about you leading the Saints to retake the city of Stilwater. It starts off with a prison break, and from there you can go after each gang however you want.

I first went after the Ronin, then the Brotherhood, then the Sons of Samedi. The Ronin are your stereotypical asian gang: Tuner cars, motorcycles, katanas, disappointing sons. The Brotherhood is your stereotypical truck-lovin', mullet-rockin' trailer trash, and the Sons of Samedi: Crazy voodoo-practicing Caribbeans". Finally you take on Ultor
hoursPlayed: and its own private army. Fun times.\n\nSaints Row 2

reviewText:
I heard that this was a bad port and that it was nowhere as good as Saints row: The third, and sure maybe that‚Äôs true, I don‚Äôt know. All I know is that it worked fine on my computer and I really enjoyed it.
I played the third before this one and it was funny to see what happened before the goings on of the third. Seeing old characters in the new (or old depending on your perspective) city of Stillwater was pretty amusing as well. In terms of graphics, plotline and general quality: sure, it‚Äôs not as good as the third game, but for what it is, it is still pretty great.
Whereas it‚Äôs sequel is a lot more on the light hearted and jokey side, this game was a lot more serious and gruesome in terms of plot and dealing with the enemies, which was a little bit of a shock to me if I‚Äôm honest but it doesn‚Äôt make the game any less good.
The cars, their mechanics and physics all work well and the music and charm of the game as a whole is still worth the money.
If you are looking to start the franchise or already are a fan of the franchise and are looking to back track a little, do it!

reviewText: Saints Row 2 is a great game. If you haven't played the first one you should be ok (I never played the first one) the game does a good job telling you what happened, and I never felt lost story wise. However, there were some times when I felt that they referenced the first game, but it only felt like if my friends had an inside joke that I wasn't part of. Overall, the story was good, and I understood it. If you are coming at this after playing futer installments, you will notice that the tone is way different. It is much more serious and in many cases really brutal like when you are taking out key members of a rival gang. However, there is still tons of humor. Good examples being, driving around in a septic truck shooting sewage at houses to lower the property value, you and Pierce's arguments about which radio station to watch, the character interactions in general, and the news and advertisements that play on the radio. A thing that the game does really well at is the side missions. There is a huge variety of them from standard ones like stealing cars to the previously mentioned spraying buildings with sewage to lower the property value. Another thing that the game does well is the story progression. You have the freedom to really do what you want to do from the very begining. You can pick which gang mission you want to do, if you want to topple one before the other, or if you want to try to attack them all at the same time. However, my biggest problem is that there was a few more glitches than I would have liked, but I only had to restart once, and I crashed twice. Other than that the game was well designed, and all around a blast to play.

reviewText:
This game can be hilarious yet also serious. It is NOT a GTA clone, but it does have similarities. I have played this game from start to finish as well as many activities and other fun things. May I just say one main thing SR2 does better  than GTAV:
GTAV activities include: Tennis, Yoga, Strip clubs, Drinking, Golf, etc
SR2 activities include: Mayhem (where you have to cause as much damage as possible), Insurance fraud (throw yourself into cars to go flying and make money), Fight Club, Attack Helicopter (covering a drug-dealing car from above), Snatch (Oh, how this mode made me cry in my (successful) attempt at getting infinite ammo for the SMG's...), and many more fun and destructive activities. Granted, the SR series does not have as much 'polish', but I still think it is much more fun.
In this game you could be holding an innocent bystander after chucking a sticky bomb on a train. You can then throw this person infront of the train (as it passes), detonate the bomb so the train de-rails and sends itself and the person (and probably multiple cars) flying off a bridge and falling into the sea. All in the space of about a second. There are a hell of a lot of things you can do in this game, all as insane and fun as that. Get the bundle which includes this, SR3 & DLC, and SR4 & DLC. That's what I did (got it off ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) for less than ¬£15 and it has lasted me a long time. Gonna get Gat outta hell when I can :D

Problems though: The cinematics are often out of sync (which really stops any emotion in scenes), The sound quality is often terrible, and often things are out of place (E.G in one scene the phone was stuck on the other side of a guy's hand for me). It is still really fun though, and one of my favourite games.

reviewText:
A couple years ago I played this game at a friends house on the PS3, so when I got this game on sale I was pretty excited to re-visit the experience I had when playing on the PS3.

Bottom line is that this a TERRIBLE ported game. The graphics are terrible, even on the HIGHEST settings, the car mechanics are lazy and stupid, and when driving around a corner or just going straight, decently fast the frame rate goes extremely low for some reason even though my computer can run tons of other games that have better graphics on HIGH, this is an utter disappointment.

Not to mention having to get enough respect to play a mission is beyond annoying, I spent 30-an hour usually just to get enough respect to play a 15 minute mission which drives me INSANE.

In the end, even though the missions are fun and challenging it doesn't make up for many of the technical glitches, random frame rate drops, car mechanics and annoying respect.

Would get this game when is on a big sale but otherwise I would buy this on a console, or just get Saints row 3 or 4.

reviewText:
The PC version is an buggy and almost unplayable mess out the box, probably one of the worst console ports I've encountered and the DLC was never ported to PC. The driving feel laggy even in the modded game and basically requires a gamepad. For some reason the game will run too fast on most machines, something to do with the game expecting the CPU to run at the same speed as the the XBox 360's, which is a real WTF.

Saints Row Power Tools will fix the speed issue, but it needs calibrating to work properly.

There are also a couple of instances where missions may fail to complete properly, not allowing you to continue the campaign. These and many other bugs are fixed by the Gentlemen of the Row mod, which also adds a ton of fun and insane content, which I suspect influenced the feel of Saints Row 3 and 4

It was no graphical powerhouse in its day, but the graphics have held up surprisingly well for a game of it's age.

Despite all the annoying and insane bugs, for me at least it's still the best of all the Saints Row games as long as you install Saints Row Power Tools and Gentlemen of the Row.

With all it's problems, I cannot recommend this despite how much I enjoy it. If you are not up to installing mods that need calibrating in to get the game running properly, I would tell you to get Saints Row 3 or 4. However, if you feel up to a challenge, by all means go for it.

reviewText:
I know alot of people think Saints Row 2 is the best in the series. I personally disagree as I feel Saints Row 3 and 4 felt a lot more cohesive and unique to me, not to mention they are insanely fun and awesome games to play with a friend.

Saints Row 2 definitely has its strengths though. The story is really good and well written, surprisingly so for a GTA style game and the cutscenes are really well done. I also love the characters in the game and that was my main reason for getting the game and playing it.

Not a big fan of the models and textures in the game or the washed out look the game has. It looks like someone sucked out the colour from it and I think SR3 and SR4 had far better colour schemes. And obviously the PC port is really badly optimized and very shoddy. Playing this without the Gentlemen Of The Row patch is not recommended.

The sound quality is terrible as well, but I like the selection of music, especially the amount of 80's tracks.

Overall though it's a good game with a good story and lots of fun to be had if you can get it working. But personally I feel the sequels were much better games.

reviewText:
Oddly enough, I was never in to Saints Row until the 4th.  The game left a lot of questions, a lot of backstory, so I figured the only way to get answers was to go back to the beginning, or as far as I could.

There doesn‚Äôt seem to be a Saints Row 1 on Steam, so Saints Row 2 will have to do.

The first thing to note is that the game is buggy as hell.  Right out of the gate the game didn‚Äôt work out of the box on Windows 7. I needed to download a special config file to get the window to open non-full screen.  After a lot of fiddling around I was able to get the game going, but anytime the game crashed while playing full screen I had to re-paste the config file in to the correct directory just to get the game to work.  Needless to say the game has issues, and let it be your warning.

I never really felt like the game was probably a good PC port.  I always felt like the controls are some how a bit lacking.  It feels like a console game that‚Äôs on a PC that was meant to be played with a gamepad.  The AI is generally horrible, and gives you that ‚ÄúI have to aim with a stick‚Äù feeling.  Driving is relatively easy, and not that great of variety as is in later sequels.

Lets cut to the brass tacks.  Do you like explosions?  Do you like violence?  Do you like shooting someone in the face and pushing them out the window of a very tall building?

You will run.  You will kill.  You will drive.  You‚Ä¶ will spray sewage on the cops.  This is Saints Row 2.

The game in many ways is basically the same as the first.  There are different rival gangs that have taken over the city of Stillwater.  This use to be the Third Street Saints turf, but you have been in a comma for a long time after the ending of the first game.  With the help of your crew Gat (the bad ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•), Pierce (the black homi), and Shandi (the crusty stoner girl) you will battle these gangs over many planned missions laid out with cinematics.  It‚Äôs hard to say the story is good, but it contains quite a few twists that do make it into later games.  All faction missions the same basic pattern.  Small missions leading up to boss fights for the head of each faction.  Most boss fights, albeit interesting, are actually pretty easy despite the fact they may not look so in the first place.

Combat is a 3rd person shooter style.  You‚Äôre able to loadout a variety of weapons to each of your main weapon slots.  Your main weapons include, melee, pistol, shotgun, smg, assault, special, and thrown.  You can recruit ‚Äúhomies‚Äù off the street that will fight will you.  They are basically cannon fodder, another homage to the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• poor AI.

There is a wide array of places to explore in Stillwater.  There are many side activities to do as well if you have the time and patience.  My initial play through consisted of ~22 hours of game play and that was basically doing what I had to get through the faction mission.  In order to do faction missions, you have to earn ‚Äúrespect‚Äù, and you do that mostly by doing side activities.  Once you get a level of respect you can then do a faction mission.  Rinse and repeat.  There is considerable amount of content I did not touch and did not explore.  I‚Äôd be confident in saying that you could easily double that time.

As is the Saints way, you can pimp yourself, your crib, your car, and your crew.  Want to be a giant hot dog?  No problem.  Want to be a guy wearing a thong?  OK, weird, but you can.   Want ninja gang members?  Sure. That‚Äôs the fun of Saints Row 2, its wacky without being TOO wacky.  Unlike the sequels it seems less playful and more grounded in reality.  There are no real crazy weapons or vehicles.

TLDR; Overall if you‚Äôve played the sequels and are wondering about the back story I would say the game is worth the time.  I‚Äôd have a hard time saying the game is great, because it is not, but it was still a satisfying experience and for it‚Äôs time I think it was a solid effort.  It feels like a console port, has ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• poor AI, and crashes like mad, yet is fun.

reviewText: This game is the epitome of amazingness. Saints Row 3 and 4, and upcomingly, 5 got nothing compared to this. Saints Row 2 was one of the first games I purchased for my XboX back in 2009, and I still am not weary of it to this day. It has the absolute perfect blend of seriousness and comedy. Action and Laughs. You know when the characters are modelled in such a way, that they're just comedic no matter what? The characters are like that, whilst maintaining the bad-assery that comes with running a gang. This game has great controls, the driving is extremely precise, and the gameplay is fantastic. No matter how much of this game you think you've played, you can always play it some more. Maybe to find an easter egg or 5. Or maybe to explore the nuclear facility plants underground sewer tunnel. Or maybe kill mimes in the Stilwater shopping mall by shooting him with your pimp cane. I've clocked countless of hours of fun on this game. Well over 5 years' gaming worth. And I can not recommend this game enough. Honestly. If you and a friend want to have an amazing amount of fun. Purchase this game. However that being said, the game's servers are no longer up, so if you want to play with a friend, you'll need a third party software like Evolve. But believe me, it's worth it.

A better story, city and character editor than its sequel, plus more (and superior) rival gangs and challenges. The gameplay isn't as tight as The Third, but it's still darn good. Make sure you install Gentlemen of the Row, though.

edit: The first two Saints Row games required a certain level of 'Respect' in order to begin story missions. This is a garbage mechanic thankfully dropped in the next two games. If I'm the Boss, control every neighbourhood, have wiped out all rival gangs, etc., I shouldn't need to protect a pornstar or spray poop on houses in order to finish the final mission.

tl;dr: The activities in Saints Row games tend to be awful, so only do them when necessary. Your mileage may vary.

reviewText:
I've played through all the games in the Saints Row series and this installation is my favourite for a few concrete reasons.

I usually play games for the stories they tell and Saints Row 2 does not disappoint as it is packed with a wonderful telling of the player's progression after the events of Saints Row 1. I won't be giving any spoilers to ruin the fun but all I can say is, the player is back! What more could you ask for?

You will meet a host of familiar characters along the way, adding to the fun if you have played the first game. The mini-games are a ton of hilarious antics that will most certainly crack you up, much better than any of the mini-games in the whole series in my opinion.

What I liked most about this game though, is how dark the story was when dealing with the usual 4 gangs the player will meet in a Saints Row game. There is a very good balance between humour and seriousness in this installment so I highly recommend Saints Row 2 to the multitude of people who feel that the series is just made of complete, utter nonsensical writing.

reviewText: When I saw Saints Row 2 in a Humble Bundle, I jumped at the chance to grab it for myself. I am a big fan of open world/sandbox games and having already played a couple GTA titles on console and pc, I decided to give Saints Row 2 a chance. There were a lot of complaints about how people were having games that were running at faster speed than normal, but I think it is fine for Windows 8. There is a cutscene bug where the game will black screen if you don't skip it, but I found a mod that had a lot of add ons as well as fixed the minor bugs. After that, I gotta say it's one of the few games where I played beginning to end in the span of just two weeks. It's not the longest game in the world, but the story is interesting and captivating, even making me question the motivations behind each character, but also has some comedy sprinkled in. The music was bearable, so I didn't turn off the radio the second I got into any car. The controls aren't the smoothest because it's a port, but again it was fine for me so I won't hold it against them. Overall it was a great experience and I had a lot of fun. If the game is on sale and you like sandbox games, then give Saints Row 2 a shot. I'm sure glad I did.

reviewText: Despite it's fairly large hunger for high-performing hardware, the game offers a lot of entertainment for quite some while. Saints Row 2 is on the edge of reality, with both it's realistic and occasionally, quite silly missions. It's a game, that dosen't require much skill to play, but nonetheless, is great fun. Comparing to the GTA series, where I failed missions quite often, on SR2, I failed on really rare occasions. However, the wide variety of activities and diversions around Stilwater makes the easiness all worthwhile.\nAgain, on the technical side, one can't help but make comparisons with GTA (Mainly San Andreas). There is a much more advanced character customization system, which allows you to change everything from the depth of your character's forehead to his facial expressions. Although the amount of clothing in the game stores might seem small, it is possible to change the colour of the items from an extensive palette of colours. Also, SR2 offers you a wide variety of vehicles, which all, dissapointingly, seem to be pretty much identical in performance. Also, the ingame radio soundtrack is pretty poor. Especially  dissapointing was the 80s hits radio, which only featured a small handful of songs. While the things I listed were just minor issues that may only be annoying for me, there seem to be a few bugs in the game for which I had to find a solution online. Bugs, that don't allow you to progress further in the game without special consultation, are the most dissappealing.\nIn conclusion, Saints Row 2 is a good alternative to the GTA series, with a small hint of a shoot-em-up game. The story might not be as deep and the technical gameplay not as good, but it sure is fun as hell!

reviewText: Saints Row 2 is not about the story, characters or innovation. Because frankly, it barely has any of those. The story is good enough and the characters can be funny at times, but none of them match the squad members of Mass Effect or the compnions in Dragon Age. They also fall short of the characters presented in the game's comptetitor, Grand Theft Auto IV. But if you're looking for hours of open-world mayhem, then Saints Row 2's gameplay will definitely satisfy you - perhaps even more so than GTA. The character creation and customization (as well as vehicle customization) is great. It also has some multiplayer options, and while the competitive ones aren't anything jaw-dropping, the two-player, cooperative online mode in the singleplayer world is fantastic.

reviewText: Saints row 2 is one of my favorite games of all time, and up until Saints Row 4 came out, it was my favorite of the series. I've played through it 3 times already, once on console and twice here on PC. I love the feeling of the Saints criminal empire growing, such as the way the main hideout gets renovated throughout the story, to the satisfaction of opening the map and seeing purple overtaking it as you take more and more of the city. While I liked the more goofy direction Saints Row 3 and 4 have taken, the serious story here is very compelling, and while naturally not as goofy as the later entries, has a good amount of humorous moments sprinkled in alongside some much darker moments. The shooting feels generally alright, though sometimes the aiming feels just slightly off in a way that is hard to describe. Driving is fun though it has issues (more on that shortly), and there are a ton of side activities that are fun in their own right that give you rewards, such as infinite ammo for a certain gun type, infinite sprinting, and so on, for finishing all levels of that particular activity, and the character creation, oh the character creation. SR2 still has the best character customization in the entire series, it lets you create exactly what your character looks like, all the way down to their walking animation! The clothing options seem unlimited, and you can layer your clothes, something that was lost in SR3 forward that I really wish would return. But despite all the positive things, this game isn't perfect. Not by a long shot. For starters, the pc port. This is easily the second worst port I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with (First worst being Assassins Creed 3, the only port that was so bad that it was literally unplayable for me). Performance is absolutely terrible, its always a bad sign when the next game in the series both looks better and performs (infinitely) better. Even if you have a powerful enough computer to get high framerate, whenever the game loads a new chunk of the city as you drive around, the game stutters for a second, and you can kiss all hope of driving precisely in that moment goodbye. It may not sound bad, but I was always crashing into everything because of the game stuttering, and while after a certain point you get used to stuttering and can minimize its effect on your driving, you can never fully adapt to it. Speaking of crashing, you better make your desktop background something good, because with this game, you will be seeing your desktop quite a bit. This game, being a bad port from console, is probably best played with controller (though there are tweaks if you prefer keyboard and mouse) but despite this, the game doesn't show controller prompts. If you are wary about using mods, then don't buy this game, because some of the issues listed above (lack of controller prompts, some bug fixes) can be fixed by using the Gentlemen of the Row mod...Yes, they managed to screw the port up so bad you need to use mods to make it more stable. Most of my issues with this game stem from the port, only one really comes from the game itself: how easy it is to get ragdolled. I once failed a mission because I got ragdolled, and the game decided that everytime my character got up, they were just going to fall right back to the ground, while two nearby police officers laid into me with shotguns. Two enemies aren't a threat in this game, not even a little bit, yet I still died because my character decided that the pavement was the most interesting thing he had ever seen and couldn't pull himself away from it, and even when the ragdoll effect isn't glitching out, it's still annoying to get ragdolled by some enemy ramming their car into you, then pull yourself back up only to get rammed again. I have died numerous times to this and it is the only real time that the deaths felt unfair, as once that first ragdoll happened, I wasn't able to do anything to stop it happening again. Aside from occasional occurances like that where you effectively get stunlocked to death by the ragdoll effect, I really don't have anything else to complain about. If you are willing to install a mod and save obsessively to avoid losing progress when the game inevitably crashes, you will find a lot to like about Saints Row 2...Just get it on sale or something, even at the discounted standard price of $10 the port is just so bad that it isn't worth it. If you have a low spec machine or are too wary of mods, just buy SR3 instead. It's not as good, but a whole lot more stable. Something to note, however is that some people have stated that a good amount of issues with the port simply don't show up on windows 8, the game supposedly runs better and crashes less on it. I don't know how true it is, but if you are running Windows 8, it's something to consider.

Are you a crazy person like me? Do you like to make stuff kaboom? Can you enjoy a game that is half-serious and otherwise filled with utter insanity and irreverent humor?

If yes, check this out. Seriously. It's one of the best games i've ever played.

Ok bad stuff. It's a console port, and there are issues with that. The respect thing that locks you out of story missions until you are at a certain level is kinda stupid. Lastly some of the missions are a little obnoxious, like the ones where you have to chase someone in a car that moves at least as fast as yours does.

But that's really it. It's a sandbox crime game, so you know it has considerable replayability and mess-about potential. The story might have a relatively simple main thread (lets take over this city), but the smaller parts towards getting there can actually be quite good. They can also be rather dark, which is in contrast to much of the rest of a game that allows you to, for example, drive a sewage truck around spraying poo all over stuff. There is also an insane amount of character customization options, allowing you to create just about any sort of look you can imagine. Oh yes, and like any yummy PC game there's mods worth getting, such as Gentlemen of the Row (clothing, weapons, more stuff in general, etc). And so on...

Anyway, play it. It's funs. :3

reviewText: Despite it's fairly large hunger for high-performing hardware, the game offers a lot of entertainment for quite some while. Saints Row 2 is on the edge of reality, with both it's realistic and occasionally, quite silly missions. It's a game, that dosen't require much skill to play, but nonetheless, is great fun. Comparing to the GTA series, where I failed missions quite often, on SR2, I failed on really rare occasions. However, the wide variety of activities and diversions around Stilwater makes the easiness all worthwhile.\nAgain, on the technical side, one can't help but make comparisons with GTA (Mainly San Andreas). There is a much more advanced character customization system, which allows you to change everything from the depth of your character's forehead to his facial expressions. Although the amount of clothing in the game stores might seem small, it is possible to change the colour of the items from an extensive palette of colours. Also, SR2 offers you a wide variety of vehicles, which all, dissapointingly, seem to be pretty much identical in performance. Also, the ingame radio soundtrack is pretty poor. Especially  dissapointing was the 80s hits radio, which only featured a small handful of songs. While the things I listed were just minor issues that may only be annoying for me, there seem to be a few bugs in the game for which I had to find a solution online. Bugs, that don't allow you to progress further in the game without special consultation, are the most dissappealing.\nIn conclusion, Saints Row 2 is a good alternative to the GTA series, with a small hint of a shoot-em-up game. The story might not be as deep and the technical gameplay not as good, but it sure is fun as hell!
