reviewText:
Curator-esque Review
Saints Row 2 succeeds in being fun to play if you can get it working properly (see the link at the bottom of the review).  If a grittier, less-campy version of Saints Row 3 appeals to you and you are patient, you might enjoy Saints Row 2 despite its defects.

Saints Row 2 Review (Spoiler Free)
Story

Set after the events of the first Saints Row, Saints Row 2 (SR2) begins with the protagonist from the first game waking up from his (or her depending on your character creation choices) coma in a maximum security prison.  After a daring escape, your character returns to Stillwater to find it has changed beyond recognition.  It turns out that in the years your character was in a coma, the Saints dissolved and three new gangs have moved into Stillwater.  Former Saints have been arrested or are in hiding, previously held territory has been divided among the new gangs, and the Saints are leaderless.  Worse still, the mysterious Ultor Corporation has shown up and has its hands in everything from local government to law enforcement.  Starting from the ground up, your character begins to rebuild the Saints yard-by-yard, taking over enemy gang businesses, disrupting vice operations, and being a general pain in the Ultor Corporation's side.  Saints Row 2 sees the Saints stop at nothing to attain what they have in SR3.

Gameplay

SR2 differentiates itself from its contemporaries through how it handles missions.  The story missions are divided into threes (one for each gang) with one of the Saint's lieutenants handling each gang and can be completed in any order.  Subsequent story missions must be unlocked through acquiring reputation.  Reputation, cash, and character upgrades are acquired mostly through completing activities, such as impersonating a police officer for a COPS style TV show, committing insurance fraud, racing, joining a fight club, or using a sewage truck to devalue real-estate.  The variety among activities keeps them from going stale, though there are a few that are more aggravating than the rest. In addition to activities there are lots of collectables to find as a few cribs to buy and upgrade, giving plenty of reason to keep playing.  As with most open world games, your fun is increased when playing co-op though you should expect to play this with someone from your friends list since the online servers are no more.

A straight play-through without any lollygagging will take around 8-10 hours depending on your skill.

Design

I cannot run this game at max settings but if I could, I imagine it would look decent for a last-gen game.  Nevertheless, Stillwater is home to a variety of unique environments each with their own interesting sights and sounds.  Downtown is bustling, the suburbs are quiet, and the projects are dilapidated.  Guns sound powerful and explosions are devestating at times, ragdolling everything (even you) in their radius.  Each gang has its own personality, ranging from cars to member clothing and weapons.  The object physics in the game make it all the more fun, especially when most things seen on the sidewalk can be used as a melee weapon.  The radio stations have their own personalities and can be quite fun to listen to on their own.  Driving in the game is very difficult, especially in the case of motor cylcles which are hard to just keep upright.  Ragdolling can be troubling at times too.

When I first played SR2, I could not progress in the game in its vanilla state.  I had to download a mod that fixed the issues with the vanilla version.  Buyers be warned.

Final Comments
Having to Install a mod in order to run would usually put me off of a game, but I am a patient person and am willing to do a little leg work if it means I can experience something unique.  Was my money worth the time and effort?  I would answer yes.  The story in SR2 is the most interesting in the series in my opinion.  Brutal at times in terms of its story, it feels more realistic than SR3 but is far from dull.  As I said before, if you thought SR3 needed less panache and can deal with a little modding, you may find SR2 more satisfying despite its age.

The only mod I needed to download to get the game working was The Gentlemen of the Row" mod.  Here is a link to the thread that I used to get the game working where you'll find this mod along with several others that may interest you: http://steamcommunity.com/app/9480/discussions/0/846958724811426425/"

reviewText: Saints row 2 is one of my favorite games of all time, and up until Saints Row 4 came out, it was my favorite of the series. While I liked the more goofy direction Saints Row 3 and 4 have taken, the serious story here is very compelling, and while naturally not as goofy as the later entries, has a good amount of humorous moments sprinkled in alongside some much darker moments. SR2 still has the best character customization in the entire series, it lets you create exactly what your character looks like, all the way down to their walking animation! The clothing options seem unlimited, and you can layer your clothes, something that was lost in SR3 forward that I really wish would return. But despite all the positive things, this game isn't perfect. Not by a long shot. For starters, the pc port. This is easily the second worst port I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with (First worst being Assassins Creed 3, the only port that was so bad that it was literally unplayable for me). Performance is absolutely terrible, its always a bad sign when the next game in the series both looks better and performs (infinitely) better. It may not sound bad, but I was always crashing into everything because of the game stuttering, and while after a certain point you get used to stuttering and can minimize its effect on your driving, you can never fully adapt to it. Speaking of crashing, you better make your desktop background something good, because with this game, you will be seeing your desktop quite a bit. This game, being a bad port from console, is probably best played with controller (though there are tweaks if you prefer keyboard and mouse) but despite this, the game doesn't show controller prompts. Most of my issues with this game stem from the port, only one really comes from the game itself: how easy it is to get ragdolled. I once failed a mission because I got ragdolled, and the game decided that everytime my character got up, they were just going to fall right back to the ground, while two nearby police officers laid into me with shotguns. Two enemies aren't a threat in this game, not even a little bit, yet I still died because my character decided that the pavement was the most interesting thing he had ever seen and couldn't pull himself away from it, and even when the ragdoll effect isn't glitching out, it's still annoying to get ragdolled by some enemy ramming their car into you, then pull yourself back up only to get rammed again. I have died numerous times to this and it is the only real time that the deaths felt unfair, as once that first ragdoll happened, I wasn't able to do anything to stop it happening again. Aside from occasional occurances like that where you effectively get stunlocked to death by the ragdoll effect, I really don't have anything else to complain about. If you are willing to install a mod and save obsessively to avoid losing progress when the game inevitably crashes, you will find a lot to like about Saints Row 2...Just get it on sale or something, even at the discounted standard price of $10 the port is just so bad that it isn't worth it. If you have a low spec machine or are too wary of mods, just buy SR3 instead. It's not as good, but a whole lot more stable. Something to note, however is that some people have stated that a good amount of issues with the port simply don't show up on windows 8, the game supposedly runs better and crashes less on it. I don't know how true it is, but if you are running Windows 8, it's something to consider.

reviewText: Saints row 2 is one of my favorite games of all time, and up until Saints Row 4 came out, it was my favorite of the series. I've played through it 3 times already, once on console and twice here on PC. I love the feeling of the Saints criminal empire growing, such as the way the main hideout gets renovated throughout the story, to the satisfaction of opening the map and seeing purple overtaking it as you take more and more of the city. While I liked the more goofy direction Saints Row 3 and 4 have taken, the serious story here is very compelling, and while naturally not as goofy as the later entries, has a good amount of humorous moments sprinkled in alongside some much darker moments. The shooting feels generally alright, though sometimes the aiming feels just slightly off in a way that is hard to describe. Driving is fun though it has issues (more on that shortly), and there are a ton of side activities that are fun in their own right that give you rewards, such as infinite ammo for a certain gun type, infinite sprinting, and so on, for finishing all levels of that particular activity, and the character creation, oh the character creation. SR2 still has the best character customization in the entire series, it lets you create exactly what your character looks like, all the way down to their walking animation! The clothing options seem unlimited, and you can layer your clothes, something that was lost in SR3 forward that I really wish would return. But despite all the positive things, this game isn't perfect. Not by a long shot. For starters, the pc port. This is easily the second worst port I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with (First worst being Assassins Creed 3, the only port that was so bad that it was literally unplayable for me). Performance is absolutely terrible, its always a bad sign when the next game in the series both looks better and performs (infinitely) better. Even if you have a powerful enough computer to get high framerate, whenever the game loads a new chunk of the city as you drive around, the game stutters for a second, and you can kiss all hope of driving precisely in that moment goodbye. It may not sound bad, but I was always crashing into everything because of the game stuttering, and while after a certain point you get used to stuttering and can minimize its effect on your driving, you can never fully adapt to it. Speaking of crashing, you better make your desktop background something good, because with this game, you will be seeing your desktop quite a bit. This game, being a bad port from console, is probably best played with controller (though there are tweaks if you prefer keyboard and mouse) but despite this, the game doesn't show controller prompts. If you are wary about using mods, then don't buy this game, because some of the issues listed above (lack of controller prompts, some bug fixes) can be fixed by using the Gentlemen of the Row mod...Yes, they managed to screw the port up so bad you need to use mods to make it more stable. Most of my issues with this game stem from the port, only one really comes from the game itself: how easy it is to get ragdolled. I once failed a mission because I got ragdolled, and the game decided that everytime my character got up, they were just going to fall right back to the ground, while two nearby police officers laid into me with shotguns. Two enemies aren't a threat in this game, not even a little bit, yet I still died because my character decided that the pavement was the most interesting thing he had ever seen and couldn't pull himself away from it, and even when the ragdoll effect isn't glitching out, it's still annoying to get ragdolled by some enemy ramming their car into you, then pull yourself back up only to get rammed again. I have died numerous times to this and it is the only real time that the deaths felt unfair, as once that first ragdoll happened, I wasn't able to do anything to stop it happening again. Aside from occasional occurances like that where you effectively get stunlocked to death by the ragdoll effect, I really don't have anything else to complain about. If you are willing to install a mod and save obsessively to avoid losing progress when the game inevitably crashes, you will find a lot to like about Saints Row 2...Just get it on sale or something, even at the discounted standard price of $10 the port is just so bad that it isn't worth it. If you have a low spec machine or are too wary of mods, just buy SR3 instead. It's not as good, but a whole lot more stable. Something to note, however is that some people have stated that a good amount of issues with the port simply don't show up on windows 8, the game supposedly runs better and crashes less on it. I don't know how true it is, but if you are running Windows 8, it's something to consider.

reviewText: When I saw Saints Row 2 in a Humble Bundle, I jumped at the chance to grab it for myself. I am a big fan of open world/sandbox games and having already played a couple GTA titles on console and pc, I decided to give Saints Row 2 a chance. There were a lot of complaints about how people were having games that were running at faster speed than normal, but I think it is fine for Windows 8. There is a cutscene bug where the game will black screen if you don't skip it, but I found a mod that had a lot of add ons as well as fixed the minor bugs. After that, I gotta say it's one of the few games where I played beginning to end in the span of just two weeks. It's not the longest game in the world, but the story is interesting and captivating, even making me question the motivations behind each character, but also has some comedy sprinkled in. The music was bearable, so I didn't turn off the radio the second I got into any car. The controls aren't the smoothest because it's a port, but again it was fine for me so I won't hold it against them. Overall it was a great experience and I had a lot of fun. If the game is on sale and you like sandbox games, then give Saints Row 2 a shot. I'm sure glad I did.

reviewText: Despite it's fairly large hunger for high-performing hardware, the game offers a lot of entertainment for quite some while. Saints Row 2 is on the edge of reality, with both it's realistic and occasionally, quite silly missions. It's a game, that dosen't require much skill to play, but nonetheless, is great fun. Comparing to the GTA series, where I failed missions quite often, on SR2, I failed on really rare occasions. However, the wide variety of activities and diversions around Stilwater makes the easiness all worthwhile.\nAgain, on the technical side, one can't help but make comparisons with GTA (Mainly San Andreas). There is a much more advanced character customization system, which allows you to change everything from the depth of your character's forehead to his facial expressions. Although the amount of clothing in the game stores might seem small, it is possible to change the colour of the items from an extensive palette of colours. Also, SR2 offers you a wide variety of vehicles, which all, dissapointingly, seem to be pretty much identical in performance. Also, the ingame radio soundtrack is pretty poor. Especially  dissapointing was the 80s hits radio, which only featured a small handful of songs. While the things I listed were just minor issues that may only be annoying for me, there seem to be a few bugs in the game for which I had to find a solution online. Bugs, that don't allow you to progress further in the game without special consultation, are the most dissappealing.\nIn conclusion, Saints Row 2 is a good alternative to the GTA series, with a small hint of a shoot-em-up game. The story might not be as deep and the technical gameplay not as good, but it sure is fun as hell!

reviewText:
I've played through all the games in the Saints Row series and this installation is my favourite for a few concrete reasons.

I usually play games for the stories they tell and Saints Row 2 does not disappoint as it is packed with a wonderful telling of the player's progression after the events of Saints Row 1. I won't be giving any spoilers to ruin the fun but all I can say is, the player is back! What more could you ask for?

You will meet a host of familiar characters along the way, adding to the fun if you have played the first game. The mini-games are a ton of hilarious antics that will most certainly crack you up, much better than any of the mini-games in the whole series in my opinion.

What I liked most about this game though, is how dark the story was when dealing with the usual 4 gangs the player will meet in a Saints Row game. There is a very good balance between humour and seriousness in this installment so I highly recommend Saints Row 2 to the multitude of people who feel that the series is just made of complete, utter nonsensical writing.

reviewText:
Great game all around, however the PC port is simply horrendous. Get the Gentlemen of The Row mod, and be sure to turn Dynamic Lighting ingame to Simple, but also be sure to turn Ambient Occlusion to All. Dynamic Lighting at all kills FPS on any system, but leaving it at simple w/o Ambient Occlusion make the game look like complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. AO at all will not make the game unplayable, and will also improve the visuals significantly. Now, the game itself:
PROS:
-Great storyline (SRTT and SRIV have comparatively weak stories)
-Ridiculous amounts of fun (like Saints Row has always had)
-Stilwater > Steelport
-More character customization than SRTT (SRIV does contend, however)
-Beautifully constructed world (unfortunately marred by the otherwise horrendous PC port)
-Fun Co-Op that can still be enjoyed today thanks to mods.
CONS:
-Horrible Port (can be fixed but I still can't hit constant 60 FPS without making it look absolutely terrible)
-Won't appeal to people that prefer the newer games (this game still has a Grand Theft Auto feel to it, whereas SRTT and SRIV are completely unique)
-DAMN THE STUPID SPEEDUP BUG (ruined 25 percent of my story immersion). Fortunately it can be fixed.
-Audio quality for everything is abysmal compared to 360 and PS3. The radio stations can be fixed, but the SFX and Voices are stuck at Compressed Bit Syndrome (Mod fixes are in development)

CONCLUSION:
I got this game with the Ultimate Franchise Pack on Summer Sale for $11, so I cannot complain. However, for $10 standalone you will need to have lots of patience for me to recommend this.

reviewText:
While often considered to be a glitchy game, I recommend that you play this game to get acquainted w/ the Saint's Row's universe. This game is the opposite of GTA series in terms of the following:
1. No serious storyline, just kicking enemies' asses along w/ anyone who stands in your way, even if it is a pedestrian who happens to be a hooker.
2. Fun combat using weapons that are easy to use.
3. A hilarious world w/ funny physics and gameplay mechanics that makes you do whatever you wish.The customization of characters alone is a thing that can provide you with ample laughter.

Cons:
1. If you take it seriously, you won't like it.
2. Have glitches and bugs, but mostly unnoticeable.
3. Drag, alcohol and curse included (should be in Pros, I know).

Get it, play it and get ready for Saints Row III.

reviewText: *THIS REVIEW IS ON THE SINGLEPLAYER ONLY*\n\nThis game is an underrated classic! From the amusingly dark story of the fall and rise to power, to its rich environment where players have the opportunity to explore a city full of life and diversity. This ten-dollar game is worth all your money, and will leave you satisfied. To sum up the game as best as I can, it's basically all the flaws that GTA 4 had, except done right! I won't try to go deep into the story, since that'll probably spoil the first game. I'll just say that it's one of those plots where the protagonist's power has fallen, and he tries to reclaim it by building his own empire, while having to face conflict with the men who are in his path. Sounds edgy, right? Well, the genius writers decided to have this story take place in a diverse environment where you can be serious one minute, and be a crazed psychopath the next (something that GTA 4 failed to do). This is what makes the game shine; you just watched a cutscene of a main character being killed off, and to gain respect to move further on within the storyline, you can take part in these activities. These activities involve throwing crazed fans into helicopter blades in order to protect a celebrity, or committing insurance fraud by getting run over by on-coming vehicles (it's as fun as it sounds). While we're on the topic of the diversity in the game, the map's been completely re-designed from the first game to where nothing looks the same (different buildings, different environments, and many unique locations), and the NPCs' style are set to fit in with the environment (Goths, Yuppies, Rednecks, College Kids, and etc.). In my own opinion, this is truly a great, unappreciated game! I definitely recommend it! But, I can tell a lot of Rockstar fanboys are going to disagree me with that, and label the game a GTA Clone". reviewText:
Saints Row 2 is still to this very day an incredibly fun game to play once you get into it. It may not have the depth and content of a GTA game, but it's got a lot of charm and just pure fun.

The city of Stillwater is a sprawling metropolis that feels alive and filled with detail. It may be relatively small compared to the worlds of newer sandbox titles, but each area is unique and memorable.

The gameplay, as I said previously, is incredibly fun. Reckless driving and well-made combat is the essence of the game and key to what makes it what it is. It feels tight (although the handling could be a little better, but I understand in the context of the game it makes sense to be poor) and the systems are easy to get used to.

However, this basic gameplay is somewhat ruined by the Respect system, which I feel brings the game down. The Respect system basically entails that you must fill up your Respect bar to play missions. This is done by doing Activites around the city. My grudge with this is that the game forces you to play what would be considered side missions" or trivial activities in other games in order to enjoy the main meat of the game. There's about 10 or so of these different activities and 5 levels of them can be completed each

reviewText: This is a very well done game. Its surprising how well it runs on the PC, as it originally was supposed to be run on console. The characters are very well done, the plot is consistent and there are many twists and turns on the adventure throughout the game. The audio was a bit static-y, but I got used to it after a while. I played this game for a few hours, keeping my attention throughout. My game blackscreened, however, and I heard nothing but guns firing. Its alright though, it only took me half an hour to get the game to run in the first place as it kept crashing on start up. I recommend this game to everyone else. My screen was black for ten minutes at least, and then afterwards the guns stopped firing and I heard soft voices. The voices kept cutting out, but its still a good game. I tried to quit the game as it obviously wasnt going to work again, but it wouldnt quit. The voices came back, and I had to launch task manager in order to quit the game. My computer thought I was still in game, so I had to alt-shift on my desktop and it went back to normal.\n\n10/10, its a great game and everyone should play it at least once.

Saints row 2 is a great open world game, the world is filled with content and side activities and you can choose what you want to do to earn extras and respect to do missions. There are 3 story paths that you can do in whatever order you want to.

reviewText:
Brilliant game. While the trailers may make it seem that Volition doesn't take story or character seriously, Saints Row 2 is just a great game overall. And, yeah, the story isn't the strong point, but this ain't no drama with loads of dialog. The protagonist doesn't have time for that. Instead, you'll mostly find yourself in gun fights, helicopter fights, boat fights, fist fights, etc, while also taking over the city and taking back your territory.

Set about five years after Saints Row 1, the protagonist wakes up from their coma and you get to re-imagine him/her due to their severe burns from the explosion at the end of the first game. I opted for a British male so from this point on, I'm referring to the protagonist as a he. When he wakes up, he realizes he's in jail and immediately remembers why. You break out with Carlos who joins your gang later as a Lt. The Boss (protagonist) realizes that he has to become the leader of the 3rd Street Saints and decides to free Johnny Gat during his trial because of all the killing he did the first game. The two of you recruit three Lts, Shaundi, Pierce, and Carlos, and from there, you start to take over Stillwater, one district/mission at a time.

What's truly remarkable about this sequel is the cinematic direction they chose with the cut scenes. The cut scenes are simply amazing and I even went ahead and watched some of them twice, just because they were that great. The writing is pretty good, and there are 80000 lines of dialog, over twice from the first game. The protagonist speaks in this one, giving him a more rounded personality versus being a drone. The overall story is nice, and they were aiming for hyper realism, as in over the top, bizarre action. There are activities on the side, usually street racing, causing chaos, trail blazing, insurance fraud, etc, which is definitely a lot more fun than bowling with your cousin.

On the tech side, the graphics are decent. The PC port isn't amazing, but it's functional and you're actually able to play it. Can't say the same about GTA IV. Saints Row 2, being a 2008 release from a lesser known company, is definitely not a  great looking game, but the overall city design and character design, and how much customization there is makes up for it. The devs definitely put a lot of thought in the overall feel of the game. I really enjoyed making money and buying cribs, building an empire, more or less.

Great game.

9.0/10

reviewText:
Saints Row 2 is a really bad port. It runs horribly and is nearly unplayable at times.

But god damn is it fun. Both in gameplay and story, SR2 is one of the most fun single player games I've ever played.

Pros
+car, plane and boat handling
+fun, varied missions
+nice selection of guns
+good story driven by great, funny characters
++great music

Cons
-poor audio quality
-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• port
-shotty animations at times
-general stuttering at times

Don't let the cons turn you away from this glorious game, with the small budget they had to make this game, they made a spectatular one.

The original Saints Row isn't on PC, so you can start the series with this. They explain the events of the first game pretty well, but even if you are a little lost about the background of the characters, you can enjoy the 3 gangs and ultor stories presented to the player.

By far the best all round Saints Row in the series.

reviewText:
Nothing pains me as much as seeing a series take an immediate decline. Saints Row 2 was the last one (and unfortunately only the second, obviously) to actually capture that true gang image. Sure SR3 had gangs, but you were suddenly big celebrity man and it just felt like a complete mockery.

If you want a game for story involving gangs, look towards this.

reviewText:
A great open world game. Saints row 2 is a perfect blend of comedy and drama, and times it at the right moments. No awkward jokes during a death scene, and no out of place dramatic moments in what is meant to be a funnier part. The world is great, and feels more like a real city than any GTA clone I've played before. One of the best city maps I've seen. In the world you can do crazy things like jerking of on top of a moving train, handstanding on cars, hijacking a sewrige truck to spray, etc. There are a few dramatic scenes involving  a dramatic mercy killing, and watching a friend die without being able to do anything. . The game feautures a wide array of well developed characters, 3 gangs, each you will come to hate. The story is not that great but I enjoyed it and found myself invested and actually caring about what happens. The side activities are ok, some really fun but others are a chore and you will only play them to earn respect. The city of Stilwater is a great map. While not being huge, the level of detail is amazing, especially compared to Just Cause 2 or the late Saints games. Buskers, skaters, mimers and orange singers fill the streets. There is a lot of interiors, gun stores, fast food chains, strip clubs, shopping malls etc. It is like a real city. Another defining thing about Saints Row is the customisability. You choose your appearence, taunt, compliment, voice. It is one of the best character creators I've seen. I've heard about port issues, but in my playthrough I never experienced them.


8.6/10

MY PERSONAL playtime compared to cost of game

$10/52hr

That's around 20c for an hour.

reviewText:
Having played the excellent Saints Row: The Third and Saints Row IV, I decided to go back to the previous titles in the series.

Saints Row 1 for the Xbox 360 was just pure crap. hate, hate, hate. Avoid.

Then there is the flawed gem that is Saints Row 2.
Volition fixed up *alot* of the problems that was in Saints Row and added so much more.
Pity they did'nt remove the RPG Grind aspect that is the 'Earn Respect to play Story Missions' Aspect, but at least it is more fun to do it. I recommend you Grind until you hit Level 50 of Respect, you'll be good to last until the end of the game.

Up front, the PC version is Glitched and has problems. Installing Gentlemen Of The Row ( http://idolninja.com/sr2.php ) *before* starting the game would help you alot in the long run. The game will still crash to the desktop at random long sessions, so save often. After the end of every mission. The Glitches do add some extra humour to the game, especially duri/ng the cutscenes. Check out my screenshots of the game in my steam screenshot archive to see a few.

Audio: Good use of sound effects, crap loads of recorded audio for the pedestrians.
The voice actor of Roman from Grand Theft Auto IV does some radio ads. He could be walking around somewhere too!

Graphics: It was made in 2008. Saints Row The Third came out in 2011. Massive difference. Despite that, it is still very servicible. I was not at all cringing while playing.

Controls: Passable with a keyboard and mouse, but much better using a controller. Thanks to the Gentlemen of the Row mod, it can change all ingame control prompts for the Xbox 360 gamepad (which is what I used) or the Playstation 3 gamepad.

Gameplay: In comparision to Saints Row The Third and Saints Row IV, I still found it to be enjoyable. Even though I rate Saints Row IV as the most fun Saints Row I have played so far, Saints Row 2 is still a good fun game to play. Grab it when its on sale, its worth it! Although the current price of $10 is still okay, but it can't beat the $3.45 that I paid for it.

Story: Ah! We have reached the creamy center! This is where Saints Row 2 shines. Out of all the Saint Rows so far, the storyline dailed in and stranglehold the pure gangster vibe of the 90's. Freedom - Remorse - Brutality - Revenge - Violence, yet it still finds time to put in alot if humour. The later games may have instilled more humour, Sainst Row 2 is a good mix of fairly seriousness and comedy.

I freakin' loved Saints Row 2. Tryed to play it on the PS3, hated the controls. So much better to play it on PC, despite the glitches it has.

reviewText:
In 2008, my favorite sandbox-style game wasn't Grand Theft Auto IV. It was Saints Row 2. And no matter how many weird looks my friends gave me, I was adamant about my stance on the matter. Saints Row 2's superior driving mechanics and shooting systems won me over, as did the game's irreverent sense of humor. If all you wanted to do was steal some cars, ride around, blow stuff up, and take part in diverse, fun activities, Saints Row 2 was your game. Which is why it pains me to say that the PC version of Saints Row 2 is a big disappointment.
Saints Row 2 is a pure sandbox experience that doesn't pretend to be anything more. It's a digital playground of toys and games for the mature gamer with a childish sense of humor. One minute you can be blowing up rival gangs from the air with an attack helicopter, while the next you can be destroying entire city blocks with a rocket launcher. You can engage in some not-so-discreet intimate activity around one corner, only to end up flinging sewage all over to lower property values around the next. Care to take over the city at gunpoint, building a crime empire through your mastery over drugs, cars, women and hustle? Or do you just want to run around town in a trench coat, flashing people for kicks? Saints Row 2 doesn't care; it encourages you to do what you want, when you want. This is the kind of game you could spend dozens upon dozens of hours on and never feel like you're doing the same thing twice.
Performance-wise, the PC version of Saints Row 2 doesn't hold a candle to the console versions. The framerate is choppy throughout, and the distance at which cars are visible is significantly less than in the console games. High-speed driving is frustratingly difficult when there are lots of vehicles onscreen, especially in time-sensitive missions. And so just the basic act of playing the PC version of Saints Row 2 becomes a chore in itself.
Saints Row 2 offers a wide array of multiplayer options, but I had trouble getting the worthwhile ones up and running. The console versions featured nearly seamless drop in and drop out" multiplayer

reviewText:
At the end of the day, Saints Row 2 is nothing more than a sub-par GTA clone in terms of quality, both graphical and gameplay.  That being said, Saints Row 2 leaves its mark by boasting the true spirit of the sandbox genre better than any game I've ever witnessed.  Comparisons to GTA IV are unnavoidable - the trailer itself makes multiple references to the acclaimed title - but this title's largest claims to fame against GTA are its innumerable efforts to be wacky, over the top, and at the end of the day, fun, while its competitor has taken the path of harsh, gritty realism.

One of these efforts has drawn me to the conclusion that someone on the dev team was psychotically mad, and that is the sheer extent to which you can customize your, well, everything.  From the type of paint on your cars to the angle at which you wear your bowler hat, Saints Row 2 is also one of the best Second Life simulators you can dream of.

The story and characters aren't very engaging, but at the end of the day, this game isn't about the story, but about the gameplay, which can be described with a very hard to come by word in today's gaming industry - fun.  Sure, it's fun to an extent of near insanity, but it's fun none-the-less.

reviewText:
The game follows all the GTA series traditions: A city with streets full of cars to steal and pedestrians to beat up (Who cares about those suckers? They respawn!), same  weapon category system and missions structure. But still, there are some major differences from GTA 4 and earlier games:

-More activities. After you complete all the missions, you still have plenty of activities to complete. And those are not just taxi or other delivery missions or hidden item collecting, they are way more entertaining. For instance, you get to jump in front of a car to fly away after it hits you (insurance fraud),  you get to spray crap all over the city (Septic avenger) or dress up as cop and fight ninjas fighting pirates (FUZZ)!
-Fun. Seriously, this game is insanely hilarious. You get to meet some funny characters, get into some aburd situations, hear some funny ads on radios... wait why am I reciting all this? Just go and check it out yourself!

One major drawback: too short, only 45 missions!

reviewText:
If you are familiar with Saints Row: The Third - you can skip the part that is directly below (right until the first line space). You can build your own character from scratch, literally, you have pure freedom which you can only dream of in Grand Theft Auto games. This game is not realistic, and it's a big advantage. And there are lots of crazy things to do. And if you are tired by these - you can simply enjoy the story. While it isn't very deep or insightful, it is not cheesy at all, this game has an excellent blend of genuine drama and humour. And freaking action, of course. I guarantee you will be tense and anxious about what will happen next.

This game is, in my opinion, absolutely superior to Saints Row: The Third. Don't take me wrong - SR3 is a quite decent game, but way too nuts. Saints Row 2 perfectly mixes humour and genuine drama in itself and it has that specific chilly, gloomy and original atmosphere I haven't seen in any other game yet.

Graphics aren't bad - if you have a very powerful computer (and I really mean it - this game is badly optimized and that's the only defect I can think of, the game runs quite fine on my computer though, which is Intel Dual Core 2.5, 3 GB of RAM and GeForce 430 GT 1GB). Otherwise I agree - graphics are very bad. Driving seems to be clumsy, too, but if you get used to it, it ain't that bad.

If it weren't for these defects, I'd sincerely give this game 10/10. But due to these defects, I have to give it 9/10.
One of the best games of my life.

reviewText:
After a whirlwind tour of Saints Row the Third, IV, and Gat Out of Hell, I decided it was finally time to give the originals their fair shake - or at least Saints Row 2, the only one of the first two games currently ported to PC. I wanted to see where it had all begun, and what I'd heard from other fans about SR2's sandbox being even more expansive than the latter sequels was also encouraging. While there were also warnings of it being a bad port, I was reassured that the superlative mod pack by IdolNinja, Gentlemen of the Row, addressed many of the issues admirably, while broadening the base content of the game considerably. Needless to say, I was excited.

However, I am finding myself disappointed with the game. Perhaps I have been spoiled by starting with the Third, but I get the sense that if I had started with Saints Row 2 I might never have glommed on to the series the way I have.

The first issue is vehicles. They're a huge part of Saints Row 2, and the game offers even greater customization of them than its sequels. None of that is enough to make up for their atrocious handling. Even with mods, there wasn't a moment when I wasn't cursing with frustration at them. Their amped up sensitivity makes any fine movement virtually impossible, which is pretty crucial if you're, say, piloting a helicopter at treetop level between buildings.

Second, are the activities. I thought that they were frustrating in SR3, but God DAMN, I didn't know what frustrating was until this. Each activity needs to be completed at least six times at ramping levels of difficulty to be fully completed, and there are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s of them. Activities that were easy and fun in SR3, such as Mayhem or Heli Assault, are soul-destroying exercises in futility here. I don't even want to think about what activities I hated from 3, like Escort, are like in 2,

Third, the clothes. A lot of harumphing is made by veterans of the series about the superiority of 2's clothing system over its sequels, that it allows for layering and greater customization. The latter is partially true - most clothing has at least three parts that can be colored independently, and other items allow you to choose between a variety of logos to place on the same shirt. That said, the noise about layering is just that - noise. Overall the selection of clothing doesn't seem to be much greater than what you see in Planet Saints in the Third - in fact, it seems any one store in the Third has a greater variety of clothing than all the stores in this game.

It's a hard pill to swallow. This is a game I desperately want to enjoy. That said, I have a hard time seeing, if you're a veteran of the sequels or a newcomer to the series, what you will enjoy. Perhaps I'll think better of it after playing it more, but at present this possibility looks remote.

reviewText:
All legends have to start somewhere.  The Saints Row series has become a major brand name in its own right, arguably outclassing the GTA series which it originally imitated.  Despite that, it didn't really rise to greatness in its first iteration.  No, what put Saints Row on the list of truly great series was its second offering, a dramatic improvement compared to the first game.  While later games in the series offered further improvements in some areas, there are several reasons why many Saints Row fans cite this game as the best the series has to offer, and one of the best Open World games ever made.  I'm not convinced it's the absolute best game on that measure, but it is at the very least in the top 5.

Why such high praise?  Quite simply, Saints Row 2 has a near perfect combination of gameplay and story elements which suit the Open World game style perfectly, some which are hard to find anywhere else.  Customizable vehicles, customizable player character, rich and varied minigames/diversions, an organically laid out city with surprising depth and complexity, wide variety of vehicles, weapons, and enemies, on and on and on.  There is an immense amount of content packed into this game beyond the core plot, which is long enough on its own.  Factor in the actual plot, the numerous side quests, activities, and diversions, and then cap it off with the sheer number of unmarked random distractions that Stilwater has to offer, and it soon it becomes clear just how much gameplay there is here, all of it fun.

And speaking of the plot, let's talk about that briefly, without spoilers of course.  The game picks up directly from the last game, more or less anyway given that the player character has been in a coma for several years.  The former conquests of the Third Street Saints have come undone in the years since, and its up to the Protagonist to put the Saints back together and back on top of Stilwater's criminal heirarchy.  From there it goes a variety of places, some cliche, some over-the-top, a great many comedic, but also a good deal of legitimately dramatic places as well.  Many games have that variety of tone and seriousness, but I have to say that Saints Row 2 does one of the better jobs of balancing those elements.

Of course no game is truly perfect, and Saints Row 2 has some flaws to be sure.  PC version and compatibility issues aside (which there are several), the game includes a few frustrating design choices, particularly when it comes to co-op play.  There are minor issues which the following games fixed, things like a complete lack of on-screen instructions for certain special control situations, like operating Tow Trucks.  Beyond that, one of the biggest issues is that virtually anything one player does in any kind of menu will in some way prevent the other player from doing certain things, or possibly will pause the game entirely.  One person accessing a car garage anywhere means the other will have to wait, and the same goes for some types of player customization.  The biggest issue though is the phone menu, a vital tool for certain side missions and diversions, will completely pause the game for both players, effectively locking one player out of the game entirely whenever the other dials the phone.  This is also true for anything off of the main game menu, and there are a lot of things which are.  It's honestly one of the worst problems in the Saints Row series, something which persists even through to the latest iteration.  Outside of design choices, certain missions and diversions have rather uneven difficulties at times, with everything progressing at tolerable difficulty until you reach one frustratingly picky/difficult part.  Many games have this issue, but the missions in Saints Row which suffer from it seem especially bad for some reason. Fortunately, none of these issues are absolute dealbreakers.  The game is still amazingly fun from start to finish.

What anyone curious about Saints Row 2 should take away from my review is this: Saints Row 2 is a truly outstanding Open World crime game, one of the most fun examples of the genre.  While there may be better games in the genre out there, depending on your tastes, this is still the game which put the Saints Row series on the map as it were, establishing it solidly as a direct competitor to the then-untouchable GTA series.  If you like Open World games, you should give this one a try.  If you have any love of the Saints Row series, then you absolutely NEED to play this game.

reviewText:
Great game, in fact, this is the best of the series, or at least that's what I think. BUT, it is an awful port, probably one of the worst ports in the history of modern PC games. Only recommended if you don't mind chasing after mods to fix games, bad framerates, poor visuals and a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of bugs all around. Even after installing the mods that make it playable (thanks Gentlemen of the Row Team and PowerTools for saving the game, and I really mean THANK YOU), the port still doesn't work how it should even with this mod, but it makes it playable, and adds better support for your controllers. Outside of this, other problems such as awful audio quality compared to the console versions make this awful port seem even worse. To make it even worse, because of the Gamespy shutdown a few years ago, one of the best features of this franchise, the full co-op, is unavilable over the internet unless you use a LAN tunneler.

This is the worst port I've ever played, and I have GTA IV PC. Buy it on console instead, no one will think less of you, the support for this game is dead anyway, with neither CD Projekt or Volition are acknowledging this game port exists, outside of a few ex-modders. An alternative is to just play Saints Row: The Third or Saints Row IV, as those are both solid games as well, with good ports, even if they aren't quite as good.

If the game played how it did with the mods I mentioned downloaded, I'd recommend this to everyone, it really is a brilliant game. What we got was a terrible port of a brilliant game, and no matter how good the game could be, it doesn't make up for what they released it as. Avoid, or buy it on XBOX 360 where the co-op and the game still works without any effort.
